title: Lightning Creek Fire
field_incident_overview: The Lightning Creek Fire was ignited by lightning on 7/30/2025. It is burning up the Lightning Creek Drainage in the 2018 Cougar Fire scar. There is one type 6 engine and two overhead assigned to the fire.

title: Island Creek
field_incident_overview:
The Island Creek fire was detected the evening of July 31, 2025. The fire is burning in steep terrain on the Moose Creek Ranger District near Sob Point, approximately 14 air miles north of Elk City, ID. It is approximately 11 air miles southeast of Lowell, ID.

As hunters and recreationists visit the Forest for fall hunting seasons and other activities, they should be aware of the expanded closure order. It includes parts of the forest bounded by the Coolwater Road, the Falls Point and American River Road, NFSR 464, NFSR 1129, NFSR 1119, NFSR 223, the Eagle Mountain Trail (#206), the Coves Lake Trail (#3), the Big Rock Trail (#693), the Three Links Trail (#495), the Mink Peak Trail (#438), and the High Line Ridge Trail (#626). For a map and more details on the closure follow this link: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r01/nezperce-clearwater/alerts/expanded-selway-river-area-closure-7-29.

title: Rosa Fire
field_incident_overview:
Rosa Fire Last Update          Final Rosa Fire Map         

The fire remains within the existing perimeter, no growth is expected. Fire Suppression repair has been completed.  

Management of the fire has been turned back to the local units (Riverside County Fire, and the San Bernardino National Forest.

Closures:  

Pinyon Campground, Santa Rosa Truck Trail and associated remote "yellow post" campsites, Cahuilla Tewanet Viewpoint, and the Sawmill and Cactus Springs Trail have reopened for public use.

title: 2025 BDF Gold Fire
field_incident_description: Wildfire
field_incident_overview:
INITIAL SITUATION: San Bernardino National Forest firefighters responded to reports of a wildfire one mile NE of Holcomb Valley Campground in Big Bear, in the morning of Monday, August 4th, 2025. Holcomb Valley Campground was evacuated and remains closed.  Local Forest road closures are now in effect. 

 

CURRENT SITUATION: 

The ending size of the Gold Fire is 1036 acres due to more accurate mapping of the fire perimeter. Today the San Bernardino National Forest Type 3 Team is taking over the fire.  Mop-up, suppression repair, mitigating hazard trees and putting out the few places with a little smoke in the interior of the fire area are the main tasks in cleaning up this fire.  An excavator will also be working to move rocks back in place along the John Bull Trail that were moved for firefighter entry.  It will also be used to deck the logs of cut hazard trees.

Note that this is the final current situation update unless significant activity occurs.


FOREST VISITORS: A Temporary Forest Closure Order 05-12-52-25-03 has been implemented. Holcomb Valley Campground, John Bull Trail, and Holcomb Valley, are being impacted by the Gold Fire. Snags (dead standing trees), and widow-makers (broken limbs suspended in tree branches) ash pits (large holes filled with hot ash and embers from incinerated trees and shrubs), equipment and fire personnel are some of the many safety risks to the public. For your safety and the safety of our firefighters please honor the Forest Order and stay clear of the closed area.

This order is a temporary order and will remain in place until September 7, 2025. The San Bernardino National Forest has 900 miles of Off Road trails for your enjoyment during the closure.

The full closure order and map can be viewed here: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/sanbernardino/alerts/gold-fire-area-closure

 

AREA CLOSURES: The following recreation sites and Forest Service roads are temporarily closed for fire personnel and public safety.

title: Elk RBX Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Elk fire was discovered on Saturday, August 2nd as a lightning strike on private land in the Oak Ridge area. Drought with severe and extreme weather conditions along with two days of red flag warning caused heightened fire activity. Residences were evacuated from the area. As weather conditions changed and remained favorable for the Elk Fire, crews were able to gain substantial line around the Elk Fire. 

The Elk Fire is currently reported as being 100% contained.

For latest on evacuation notices and to sign up for reverse 911

Rio Blanco County: https://rioblancoalerts.genasys.com/portal/en

title: Stoner Mesa Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Stoner Mesa Fire has been burning along Stoner Creek and on Taylor Mesa. Fire behavior had been extreme early in the incident due to the prolonged lack of moisture, low humidity levels, strong shifting winds and lots of available fuel. Heavy rainfall in late August and into September has significantly reduced fire activity. Fire activity is minimal, with only isolated pockets of heat. Firefighters continue to look for hot spots, and are also focused on repairing firelines and roads in the fire area and removing equipment no longer needed.  

Hunters: A Fire Area Forest Closure is in effect for the fire area, although the size of the closure was reduced on September 3, 2025. See the complete order and a map under the "Closures" tab on this site.

title: Lee Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Lee and Grease fires were discovered on August 2nd as lightning strikes on Bureau of Land Management managed land in the Piceance Creek area. The Lee and Grease fires quickly met to be known exclusively as the Lee fire. Drought with severe and extreme weather conditions along with multiple days of red flag warnings and heightened fire activity, the Lee fire grew over 100,000 acres in eight days. Firefighters have been working to find areas of opportunity in the southern area of the fire to reduce spread. 

For latest on evacuation notices and to sign up for reverse 911 for your county follow - 

Lee and Elk Fire Evacuation Zones Map (Rio Blanco and Garfield Counties) - https://bit.ly/lee-fire-zones

Rio Blanco County: https://rioblancoalerts.genasys.com/portal/en 

Garfield County Register for Alerts: https://garco911.com/emergency-notification-system/ 

Garfield County Incident Updates and Subscribe to emails: https://www.garfieldcounty.net/

title: Bronco Fire
field_incident_description: The Bronco Fire is a full suppression wildfire.
field_incident_overview: The Bronco Fire is footprint is on the San Carlos Apache Agency, located 30 miles northeast of San Carlos, Arizona. The lightning-caused fire was reported on on August 3, 2025 burning in timber, chaparral, and brush.

title: Gill Gulch Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Gill Gulch Fire was reported August 4th and is located approximately seven miles south of Lincoln, MT. The fire is in patrol status and firefighters continue to monitor the fire daily for heat and work on mop-up operations.

There are no closures in place.

title: Beulah Fire
field_incident_overview:
Over the next few days, the Northern Utah Team will focus on repair activities, continue to increase completion, and work towards opening closure areas as soon as it is safe to do so. 

Fire suppression repair activities include repairing control lines created by heavy equipment and handcrews. Specifically, crews rehabilitate these control lines into a more natural state by replacing soil and overlaying the area with brush and other forest debris. Waterbars are constructed to direct water off of fire lines to prevent erosion. These efforts are vital to restoring the ecosystem its natural state and providing proper stewardship of our forest.

Summit County Sheriff’s Office has updated evacuation notices. Hinckley Boy Scout Camp has been downgraded from GO to SET. Christmas Meadows has been downgraded from SET to READY. Manorlands and Uintalands remain in READY status.

title: Indian Creek
field_incident_description: The Indian Fire is a full suppression wildfire.
field_incident_overview: The Indian Creek Fire started August 5, 2025, on the Fort Apache Indian Reservation. It was burning in grass, brush, Juniper and Ponderosa Pine in steep and rugged terrain that was challenging for firefighters to access.

title: White Sage Fire Burned Area Emergency Response BAER
field_incident_overview:
The White Sage Fire was started by lightning on July 9, 2025, near the community of White Sage approximately 15 miles southeast of Fredonia, Arizona, on the Bureau of Land Management’s Arizona Strip District. The wind-driven fire quickly grew onto the North Kaibab Ranger District despite the efforts of wildland firefighters who were able to respond a short time after the fire was first detected.

Driven by hot, dry, windy weather, the fire quickly grew and crossed onto the North Kaibab Ranger District by July 10. Command of the fire transferred command to the Color Country Team 2 Incident Management Team July 10 and was transferred on July 13 to Great Basin Complex Incident Management Team 6. 

A Burned Area Emergency Response (BAER) Team was ordered to assess the effects of the White Sage Fire to critical Forest Service values within the fire perimeter. The Team, led by BAER Team Leader Paul Brown, began assessing the Fire on August 1 and completed their findings and recommendations briefing to the Forest leadership on August 11.
field_title_and_unit: AZKNF White Sage Fire Burned Area Emergency Response BAER

title: Mountain Fire
field_incident_description: The Mountain incident is located near the area of the Mammoth fire which burned in July.  U.S. Forest Service-Modoc National Forest  Fire resources, including engines, crews, and fire suppression aircraft, are responding to a new fire incident visible from HWY 139 near Casuse Mountain with more resources on order. The Mountain Fire is approximately 250 acres burning in grass and brush with a moderate rate of spread.
field_incident_overview:
🔥8/12 Mountain Fire update 3:30 PM  🔥

The Mountain Fire is currently 30% contained at 980 acres, with no significant growth reported. The aerial support during this incident has been crucial, aiding in the fire line construction for the firefighters working on the ground. 

Today, crews are continuing mop-up operations, focusing on full suppression and containment of the fire. 

**Fire Weather:** Isolated critical conditions are expected today and Wednesday due to gusty winds and low relative humidity (RH). Dry conditions are expected to persist throughout the week, with temperatures gradually returning to near seasonal norms. A dry front is predicted to move through the region today and continue into Wednesday, which may bring increased wind speeds. These winds, coupled with low daytime RH, could create isolated areas of critical fire weather conditions. 

The public is urged to stay clear of areas where firefighters are actively working and to help prevent new fires from starting.

title: Crosho Fire
field_incident_overview:
Overview:

  • Report Date: August 11, 2025
  • Location: 7.5 miles northwest of Yampa, Colorado in Rio Blanco County near the Routt County line.
  • The fire spread into Routt County and onto private land.
  • Containment is reported at 100%.

Forest Information

  • A Forest area closure is in place (9/12/25): Order, Map

title: Rock Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Rock Fire was established as an incident at 12:37 a.m. on August 13, 2025. It was one of several lightning-caused fires that started between the evening of August 12 and the early morning hours of August 13 across the Boise and Payette National Forests. Located approximately 1.5 miles south of Tamarack Resort, some of the smaller fires in the area were extinguished, while others merged into what is now the Rock Fire.

The fire is burning in rugged, mountainous terrain, with steep slopes on the northwest and southeast flanks. The subalpine fir understory holds a heavy load of dead and downed fuels, contributing to challenging fire behavior and intensity. 

Closures in effect

title: King Fire
field_incident_overview:
INITIAL SITUATION: A brush fire was reported at 1:00 am in the morning east of interstate 5 and north of Smokey Bear Rd. In the early hours of the fire, firefighters experienced dangerous rates of spread and the fire quickly grew to over 100 acres. The fire has continued to burn south towards Vista Del Lago. Two unoccupied RV's were destroyed at the Pyramid Lake RV park early on in the incident. The fire has attempted to cross Interstate 5 three times.

 

CURRENT CONDITION: The King fire is 100% contained. All road closures have been lifted.

 

KNOW WHERE YOU CAN FLY: Drones pose a serious risk to firefighting and can cause air operations to cease. When drones interfere with firefighting efforts, a wildfire has the potential to grow larger and cause more damage. A FAA Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) is in effect and any private aircraft or drone that violates the TFR could face serious criminal charges. For more information on drones the public can visit the FAA’s website at www.KnowBeforeYouFly.org “If you fly, we can’t!”

title: Horn Fire
field_incident_description:
The Horn fire is located on private property and DNRC-managed land between Cliff Lake and Highway 87 in Madison County, near the Montana-Idaho border. Fuels in the area are primarily grass and brushy fuels.

Horn Creek Road, Cliff Lake Road, and Wade Lake Road are open as of 8/18. Wade Lake and Cliff Lake are also open to the public.
field_incident_overview:
The Horn Fire was reported around 2:30 pm on Wednesday, August 13th. The cause of fire was lightning. 

As of Monday 8/25, the Horn Fire is 2,800 acres and 100% contained. Crews should be finishing rehab today and then demobilizing. 

Firefighters ask that everyone use caution when recreating to avoid causing additional fires. Secure chains when towing and check MTFireInfo.org for fire restrictions. Beaverhead and Madison County are in Stage 1 restrictions, meaning campfires are not allowed unless in a developed campground with an established ring. Always fully extinguish your campfire until it is cold to the touch.

title: Washington Fire
field_incident_overview:
This page is covering the Washington Fire and the nearby Sheep Spring Fire.

The lightning caused Washington Fire was discovered on Wednesday, August 13, 2025. Firefighters are working to fully suppress the fire, with the top priority being the safety of both the public and firefighters.

On Friday, August 15, 2025 at 0600, the management of the Washington Fire transitioned to Southwest Incident Management Team 1, led by Incident Commander, Carl Schwope. 

On August 19, 2025 the team assisted with the response to a new lightning caused fire on the Tonto. That became the Sheep Spring FIre and was transitioned to Southwest Incident Management Team 1 on August 20, 2025.

Both fires were transitioned to local Type 3 teams on August 23 at 0600. 

Sheep Spring Fire transitioned back to the local unit (Type 5) and was placed in monitor and patrol status as of August 25 at 4 p.m.

To sign up for evacuation notices in Gila County, visit: https://gilacountyaz.genasys.com/portal/en

To sign up for evacuation notices in Coconino County, visit: https://www.coconino.az.gov/2612/Emergency-Notification-System

title: Bivens Creek
field_incident_overview:
The Bivens Creek fire was reported on August 13, 2025, around 6:16. It is located approximately 15 miles north of Virginia City, MT. The fire is burning just to the southwest of Ramshorn Mountain. The fire area consists of thick subalpine fir timber, with a large "snag" or hazard tree component and a high concentration of dead and downed fuels. The cause of the fire was from a thunderstorm. 

On August 30, 2025, at 6 PM, Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 8 took over command of the Fire from Northern Rockies Complex Incident Management Team 6.

September 8, 2025, at 7AM, a NWCIMT8 transferred command to a local Type 3 Incident Command Team.

The Type 3 Incident Command Team transferred command back to the local Ranger District fire staff on September 17, 2025.

Madison County Sherriff issued a warning of evacuation residences in Wisconsin Creek, Noble Creek and Indian Creek. This evacuation warning was canceled on September 12.

A National Forest System Area Closure around the Bivens Creek fire was rescinded on September 12 at 6:00 p.m.

The TFR over the fire area was released on September 12.

title: Red Canyon Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 2 will transfer command to the local unit at 6 pm on 08/27/2025. A Type 4 organization will assume command of the fire.  This will be the final update for the Red Canyon Fire unless fire conditions change.

Any future inquiries for the Red Canyon Fire, please contact: 

BLM, Worland Field Office 

307-347-5100 

https://www.blm.gov/office/worland-field-office 

Hot Springs Co. Emergency Management &  Sheriff’s Department 

307-864-4649 or 307-864-2622 

https://www.hscounty.com/departments/emergency-management 

For information regarding hunting in the area, please contact Wyoming Game and Fish Cody Regional Office: 307-527-7125. 

The lightning caused Red Canyon fire was reported on Wednesday, August 14th east of Thermopolis, WY in Hot Springs County.  The fire is burning on a combination of BLM, state, and private lands.  Extreme weather conditions in light dry fuels heightened fire activity and the Red Canyon Fire grew to over 100,000 acres in 4 days.    

The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 2 assumed command of the fire on Monday August 18th with full-suppression efforts and public and firefighter safety the highest priorities. 

Containment continued to increase thanks to the hard work of firefighters.  Crews continue to patrol the perimeter of the fire and the majority of suppression repair efforts have been completed. 

The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 2 would like to sincerely thank our partners, cooperators, and residents for welcoming the team and supporting suppression efforts. Together, we accomplished the mission while maintaining both public and firefighter safety.

title: Cloudrest
field_incident_overview:
The Cloudrest Fire was reported on August 14, 2025, around 3:44 p.m., from the Alert West camera system. It is located approximately 15 miles north of Virginia City, MT. The fire is burning in thick subalpine fir timber with a heavy dead and downed fuel component. The cause of the fire was determined to be from a thunderstorm. The fire is burning at 8,000 feet in elevation.

On August 30, 2025, at 6 PM, Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 8 took over command of the Fire from Northern Rockies Complex Incident Management Team 6. September 8, 2025, at 7AM, NWCIMT transferred command of the fire to a local Type 3 Incident Management Team. The Type 3 Incident Management Team transferred command back to the local Ranger District fire staff on September 17, 2025.

title: Windy Rock Fire
field_incident_overview:
INCIDENT SUMMARY

This fire is jointly managed under a full suppression strategy between the Bureau of Land Management, the Montana Department of Natural Resources & Conservation, and the DNRC County Assist Team (CAT). The DNRC CAT Type 3 team assumed command of the fire on September 19 at 6:00 p.m.

Lightning ignited the Windy Rock Fire at approximately 1700 on August 14, 2025, in the Hoodoo Mountain Wilderness Study Area, north of Gold Creek and Phosphate in Powel County, Montana. The fire was first reported at 100 acres, but grew quickly in steep, heavily timbered terrain with significant dead and down trees.

title: Dragon Bravo Fire - DOI Burned Area Emergency Response - BAER
field_incident_overview:
On August 21, a Department of the Interior Burned Area Emergency Response (BAER) Team arrived at the Dragon Bravo Fire to identify potential risks to human life and safety, as well and critical natural and cultural resources in Grand Canyon National Park and on BLM-Arizona Strip District lands.

The BAER program is designed to address emergency stabilization issues related to wildland fire and prescribes emergency treatments to minimize threats to life and property resulting from the effects of fire. The program also addresses fire-damaged lands that are unlikely to recover naturally and to repair or replace minor facilities damaged by fire that are not critical to life and safety. This may include restoring native plant communities, treating noxious weed infestations, stabilizing trails, and replacing interpretive signs that were impacted by the fire.  

Team members are from the Bureau of Land Management, US Fish and Wildlife Service, Bureau of Indian Affairs, National Park Service, and US Forest Service. The BAER team will produce a BAER Plan specific to the Dragon Bravo Fire which will identify measures to reduce hazards and reduce further resource damage.

For more information on fire suppression efforts on the Dragon Bravo Fire, please visit the Dragon Bravo Fire Inciweb page.
field_title_and_unit: AZGCP Dragon Bravo Fire DOI Burned Area Emergency Response BAER

title: Sleeper Ranch Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Sleeper Ranch fire experienced extreme fire behavior and rapid growth during the Initial Attack. Aircraft continue to work the fire today as additional ground resources work their way to the fire.  

A Type 3 Incident Management Team has been ordered and is enroute.

title: Mire
field_incident_overview: The Mire Fire is located on the Lochsa-Powell Ranger District of the Nez Perce-Clearwater National Forests in northern Idaho approximately 25 miles west of Powell Idaho. The fire is burning in steep rugged terrain in proximity to old fire scars with many standing dead hazard trees. Fire activity varies daily from smoldering and creeping to isolated group torching and short runs when the daily inversion lifts and winds increase.

title: McAllister Fire
field_incident_description:
The McAllister Fire is located on private, state, and BLM land 3 miles south or Norris, and 3 miles north of Ennis Lake, on either side of HWY 287. The fire is burning mainly grass and scattered patches of trees.
There is an evacuation warning for residents in the area between Bradley Creek, Shining Mountains West, and US Highway 287.
field_incident_overview:
The McAllister Fire was reported around 5:15pm, Saturday August 16th. The cause of the fire was lightning. 

As of Wednesday, 8/27, the fire is estimated at 3,560 acres with 95% containment. 

Crews are working around the perimeter patrolling the line. 

Resources will continue operations with the objective to creating a cold, secure buffer around the entire perimeter working for about the next week.

The evacuation warning has been lifted as of 8/20/25 for the areas between Bradley Creek, Shining Mountains West and US Highway 287 (between mile markers 61 and 64). There are no current road closures in place.

With moisture coming the next few days, crews will be patrolling and doing suppression repair.

title: Knowles Fire
field_incident_description: Incident is located 6 miles east of Paradise
field_incident_overview: The Knowles Fire was reported on August 17, 2025. It is located along the Flathead River near the Full Curl Wildlife Management Area. The fire is being jointly managed under a full suppression strategy by the Montana Department of Natural Resources & Conservation (DNRC) and the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes (CSKT).

title: Burned Area Emergency Response BAER Dragon Bravo USFS
field_incident_description: US Forest Service Burned Area Emergency response on the 77,648 acres of Kaibab National Forest portion of the 144,504 acre Dragon Bravo Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Dragon Bravo Fire started early in the afternoon on Friday July 4th, 2025, by lightning on the North Rim of the Grand Canyon in Grand Canyon National Park. Suppression resources responded immediately. Firefighters constructed containment lines taking advantage of favorable terrain where possible to stop the fire spread.

On Friday July 11th, 2025, the Dragon Bravo Fire was affected by strong and unfavorable northwest winds associated with a passing weather front. Consequently, the Dragon Bravo Fire exhibited extreme fire behavior and jumped multiple containment features. In the following days fire behavior continued to be very active, driven by hot temperatures, low relative humidities, and continued strong winds. Facilities in the North Rim developed area were impacted during this time and damage assessments are ongoing. The fire moved onto the North Kaibab Ranger District of the Kaibab National Forest on July 23.

On Monday July 14th, 2025, at 6:00 am Southwest Complex Incident Management Team 4 took command of the Dragon Bravo Fire. They managed the fire until 6:00 am on Monday July 28th, 2025, when Southwest Complex Incident Management Team 2 took command of the fire.

On Sunday August 10th, 2025, Great Basin Complex Incident Management Team 7 assumed command of the Dragon Bravo Fire and will continue to manage the fire under a full suppression strategy while also ensuring firefighter/first responder and public safety.

In the last few days, suppression resources have made significant progress constructing and reinforcing containment lines. More favorable weather conditions have resulted in lower fire intensity in many areas. Suppression repair in select areas of the fire is in progress and will increase in the coming days. 

On Monday August 18, The Forest Service Burned Area Emergency (BAER) Team arrived to identify and manage potential risks to resources on National Forest System lands and reduce these threats through appropriate emergency measures to protect human life and safety, property, and critical natural or cultural resources on the Kaibab National Forest portion of the Dragon Bravo Fire.
field_title_and_unit: AZKNF Burned Area Emergency Response BAER Dragon Bravo USFS

title: La Plata
field_incident_description: The fire is burning in rugged terrain with heavy dead and down timber. Firefighters will continue to utilize both direct and indirect tactics to guide fire behavior toward natural barriers such as treeline scree fields and minimize threats to private property, communities, infrastructure, watersheds, and other critical assets. Access is difficult, as much of the fire is in a non-motorized wilderness area.
field_incident_overview: The La Plata Fire was reported on August 17, 2025, at 5:46 p.m. The wildfire is located on the Pike-San Isabel National Forest Cimarron and Camanche Grasslands on the south side of Twin Lakes Reservoir approximately 4 miles southwest of Twin Lakes, Colorado.

title: Derby Fire
field_incident_overview:
A Type 4 incident management organization has taken command of the Derby fire, with Matt Pfeifer as Incident Commander. 

The Derby Fire was ignited by lightning on an extremely steep cliff face in a remote area near the Flat Tops Wilderness on Saturday evening, August 16, 2025. Initial attack efforts by smokejumpers on Sunday were hindered by rollout of burning material, repeatedly igniting the slope below the main fire. 

Protection of life and property are key objectives for managing this fire.

title: Sandbar 2 Fire
field_incident_description: Lightning/Natural
field_incident_overview: In the early afternoon on August 19, fire personnel responded to a smoke report just north of Flesher Pass. Fire personnel responded immediately utilizing both helicopters and airtankers to assist hand crews putting in direct line. Dry fuels, low humidity, and warm weather led to rapid fire growth on the Sandbar 2 fire. Please be mindful of increased fire personnel on Flesher Pass Road #279 and slow down to protect our firefighters’ safety. Please avoid stopping on the road or pullouts as this affects firefighter safety and operations. On Friday August 22, at 0700 hrs., command of the fire was transferred to Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 8, with Ed Hyatt serving as Incident Commander. On August 28, 2025, at 0700, a local Type 4 incident management organization will have taken command of the fire.

title: West Fork Fire
field_incident_description: Wildfire
field_incident_overview:
The West Fork Fire Started on 8/19/2025, located 23 miles northwest of West Yellowstone, Montana, in the South Madison's just North of the Beaver Creek FS cabin, Hebgen Ranger District, Custer Gallatin National Forest.

The fire does not currently pose a threat to Big Sky. Please stay away from aviation working at Hebgen Lake. Aviation aircraft may be dipping out of Hebgen Lake. DO NOT operate drones in the fire area or the Hebgen Lake area, this will cause all firefighting aircraft to be grounded immediately. There is a temporary Flight Restriction in place in the fire area.

No evacuations ordered at this point in time.

title: Twin
field_incident_overview: The Twin Fire is a lightning caused fire burning in the remote backcountry of the North Fork Ranger District on the Nez Perce-Clearwater National Forests. Public and firefighter safety continues to be our highest priority. Please be mindful of closures and use caution when recreating in the area near the fire.

title: Dollar Lake Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Dollar Lake Fire is burning in the Green River Lakes area of the Bridger-Teton National Forest's Pinedale Ranger District. The fire was reported at 2:16 p.m. on Thursday, August 21.

Dollar Lake is located along a 25-mile dirt and gravel road that follows the Green River through the national forest. The road is a popular camping and recreation site. In a matter of hours on Aug. 21, the wind-driven fire grew from 20 acres to 600 acres in size. The fast-moving fire prompted the Sublette County Sheriff's office to immediately issue a road closure and evacuation of the area.

The cause of the fire has not been determined.

title: Willow Creek Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Willow Creek Fire was reported on Friday, August 22 on the Greys River District of the Bridger-Teton National Forest, burning in timber southwest of the town of Smoot. Initial resources included an engine and helitack working to suppress the fire, with air attack quickly on scene utilizing three helicopters and two air tankers. This is a full suppression fire.

The fire danger rating for the area remains at very high, and fire restrictions are in effect on the Bridger-Teton National Forest. Learn more by clicking this link to the Stage 1 Fire Restrictions, placed on August 12, 2025 (order #04-03-25-304)

A Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) is in effect for the Willow Creek Fire response area. Click here to read more about the TFR and the important life and safety restrictions on drone use.

field_incident_overview:
At approximately 3:00 p.m. Friday, August 22, 2025, the Little Fire started along the north side of SR-178, 5 miles west of Borel Road. Multiple agencies responded including U.S. Forest Service, Kern County Fire Department, Bureau of Land Management, Kern County Sheriff's Office, California Highway Patrol, and Caltrans. The terrain is steep and rocky, with extremely dry vegetation. The cause of this fire is under investigation.

title: Garnet Fire
field_incident_description: Lightning Fire
field_incident_overview:
UPDATES: Daily Update | Operational Update Video |

MAPS: Public Information Map

AIR QUALITY: AirNow.gov

 

Location: Sierra National Forest, Fresno County 

Acres Burned: 59,844 

Containment: 99% 

 

Start Date: August 24, 2025 

Cause: Lightning 

Residents Evacuated: 59 

Structures Threatened: 31 

Structures Destroyed: 0

 

Public Information: (559) 490-7329 

Hours: 8:00 a.m.- 8:00 p.m. 

Email: 2025.garnet.ca@firenet.gov 

 

Personnel: 746

Injuries: 19

Hand Crews: 8 

Dozers: 24

Engines: 10

Water Tenders: 15

 

Current Situation:  

Yesterday, crews mopped up remaining hot spots well inside the containment lines and began suppression repair in those areas, creating safer conditions for restoration efforts to continue. Damage Inspection Specialists (DINS) completed their survey of the fire’s impact area, finding no structures damaged or lost and providing verified information to guide recovery and repair efforts. In McKinley Grove, assessment of the giant sequoias is ongoing; to date, no trees have been noted as lost, and specialists continue to evaluate the grove and surrounding area to ensure protection and guide any needed restoration work. 

Today’s operations will largely mirror yesterday’s, with crews continuing suppression repair, and control work across the same areas. This includes pulling berms back into place, carving waterbars into slopes, and blending scarred soil back into the hillside to steady the ground, protect streams, and give cultural sites and wildlife a chance to thrive again. As needed, additional resources will be shifted to support these ongoing efforts. 

 

Weather:  

Moisture is gradually increasing across the area today, resulting in more cloud cover compared to yesterday. Temperatures are a few degrees cooler with slightly higher humidity. Winds remain terrain-driven, with afternoon gusts near 15 mph. By late tonight, a weather system moving in is expected to bring a marked increase in cloud cover and moisture. 

 

Air Quality: 

Today’s air quality is expected to be moderate overall. Smoke and haze may build up in the morning when cooler air and calm winds keep it near the ground, then gradually clear as the day warms and air movement increases. Sensitive groups should take precautions if spending time outdoors. You can check your local air quality at: airnow.gov/.    

 

Evacuations and Road Closures  

While there are no longer any evacuation orders or warnings in place, the Sierra National Forest still has a forest closure in effect. An FS-7700 form will be required to enter the closed portion of the forest. Contact the District Ranger’s Office at (559) 855-5355 to request the FS-7700 form. 

Full updates on the fire and evacuation maps are available from the Fresno County Sheriff’s Office. The evacuation map is an interactive tool that allows residents to search by their physical address, general location, or evacuation zone.  

 

Forest Closure 

The Sierra National Forest updated the Forest Closure on September 19th in response to the full suppression effort on the Garnet Fire. The partial closure order was coordinated with the Fresno County Sheriff’s Office, along with multiple local, state, and federal agency cooperators, to identify the minimum area necessary for the safety of firefighting resources and forest visitors. For a copy of the closure and map, please visit the Sierra National Forest website at: Sierra National Forest | Garnet Fire Closure Order | Forest Service

title: Emigrant Fire
field_incident_overview:
QUICK LINKS

Daily Update

Daily Maps

Daily Operations Update (Video)

Facebook:  Emigrant Fire    

Smoke: https://www.airnow.gov

Public information: https://linktr.ee/2025.emigrantfire 

 

CURRENT STATUS: As the temperature rises and relative humidity drops, conditions today may resemble those seen earlier this week, with isolated unburned vegetation smoldering and generating visible smoke within containment lines.  Forecast models show an increasing chance of rain moving in after the weekend which will further reduce fire behavior.  The primary focus for firefighters continues to be patrol and suppression repair across all divisions. 

Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 1 assumed command of the Emigrant Fire at 6 p.m. on Thursday, October 18. 

WEATHER: Today will bring warmer temperatures and lower relative humidity which could produce conditions similar to those seen earlier this week. Interior pockets of unburned vegetation may ignite or smolder creating visible smoke around the fire. A low-pressure front is moving into the area, impacting the fire Sunday evening through the middle of next week. Measurable rainfall and higher humidity will combine with lower temperatures further damping fire behavior.

RESTRICTIONS & CLOSURES:  

Information on the Willamette National Forest Emergency Fire Closure can be found by clicking on the highlighted link.

Information on road closures on the Umpqua National Forest related to the Emigrant Fire can be found by clicking on the highlighted link. 

SMOKE: The warmer and drier conditions that began Monday, September 22, could lead to increased smoke from ignition of unburned fuels within the interior of the fire. Smoke and air quality information is available at https://www.oregonsmoke.org/ and https://www.airnow.gov.

DRONES AND AVIATION SAFETY:  The Federal Aviation Administration in conjunction with Fire Management has issued a Notice to Airman (NOTAM) for all aircraft below 11,500’ MSL.  For details, please visit: https://tfr.faa.gov/tfr3/?page=detail_5_4479 Wildfires are a no-fly zone for unauthorized aircraft, including drones. If you fly, we can’t.  For more information, visit http://knowbeforeyoufly.org.  Facebook video of Air Operations and TFR's

BACKGROUND: The lightning-caused Emigrant Fire was reported on Aug. 24, 2025. The fire ignited in a remote area 3 miles southwest of Indigo Springs Campground. The fire spread rapidly through the 2009 Tumblebug Fire burn scar, which has many standing and fallen dead trees plus dense brush, and few opportunities for direct control of the fire.  Indirect control lines were established around the fire, many along roads or in locations previously used by the Tumblebug Fire. The fire reached some containment lines, but growth of the fire largely stopped due to a combination of recent rainfall and suppression activities. The fire continues to have some small growth in the southwest portion of the fire in Division M.

ABOUT THE FOREST:  The Willamette National Forest is 1,675,407 acres in size. The varied landscape of high mountains, narrow canyons, cascading streams, and wooded slopes offer excellent opportunities for visitors and make the Forest valuable for many purposes.

The Willamette National Forest is easily accessed from the Willamette Valley cities of Salem, Albany, and Eugene. Four important highways-U.S. Route 20 and Oregon State Routes 22, 58, and 126-cross the Forest. Two National Scenic Byways, McKenzie Pass – Santiam Pass National Scenic Byway and the West Cascades National Scenic Byway take visitors on a tour of tall forests and sparkling water. Over 6,000 miles of road on the Forest offer a chance to get off the beaten path.

title: Ransome Fire
field_incident_overview: The Ransome Fire was detected on August 21, 2025 and from a previous lightning storm. It is burning in the Quartz Creek drainage 11 miles northwest of Libby, MT in the 2017 West Fork Fire scar.

title: Dillon Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Dillon Fire was detected August 25, 2025 in the area of Dillon Creek just west of the Klamath River about 16 miles north of Orleans, California. The fire quickly grew to more than 300 acres by evening with extreme fire behavior and long-range spotting. 

California Complex Incident Management Team 1 (CA-CIMT 1) assumed command of the Dillon Fire on August 29. 

California Complex Incident Management Team 6 (CA-CIMT 6) assumed command of the Dillon Fire on September 11. 

North Coast Interagency Incident Management Team Type 3 assumed command of the Dillon Fire on September 24. The incident command post is at Oak Bottom Fire Station.  

Evacuations: Due to successful firefighting efforts, the Siskiyou County Sheriff’s Office has downgraded all zones to normal status as of 1:00 pm on Tuesday, September 23, 2025.

title: Swift Complex
field_incident_description: The fires, which started on the afternoon of Aug 25, 2025, are burning in steep, rugged, and remote terrain and is moving north toward Granite Peak. Most of the fire footprint is currently within the Trinity Alps Wilderness.
field_incident_overview: The command of Swift Complex is being transferred to Shasta-Trinity National Forest on September 10, 2025. The command of the Lick Fire was transferred to the Forest Service on September 7, 2025, at 7 AM. The Peak Fire is west of Lake Trinity and east of Mule Creek, while the Lick Fire is in Poison Canyon, southeast of the Carrville community.

title: Martin
field_incident_overview:
The Martin Fire was sparked from one of more than 320 strikes from a dry lightning storm that passed over the area on the evening of August 26, 2025. It is burning at high elevation, 7,000 feet, in forests that have dried out all summer with excessive heat and drought conditions. 

Level Two evacuations have been lifted for Holden Village and nearby Rio Tinto mine remediation sites by Chelan County Emergency Management. The fire received significant wetting rains over the past week and has higher nighttime moisture recovery than lower elevation communities such as Chelan or Entiat.

Closures: None. Hunters accessing high hunt opportunities, hikers, and other visitors to the Railroad Creek area are asked to stay off Holden Lake Trail #1252 and Martin Ridge Trail while active repair work is happening. Additionally, any recently burned area may include ash pits, stump holes, and other hazards created by fire activity that is not always readily visible above ground.

Evacuations: The general Holden area is at a level one “be ready”. Please visit Chelan County Emergency Management’s website at https://www.co.chelan.wa.us/emergency-management/pages/active-emergencies for official evacuation information.

Fire Information: There are no additional updates planned for this fire.

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/OkaWenNF/

title: Blue Fire - Klamath National Forest
field_incident_description: Wildfire
field_incident_overview:
On the evening of August 26, 2025 the Blue Fire ignited in the area of Blue Creek on the south side of the Klamath National Forest, just west of the Klamath River, 4 miles south of Seiad, California. 

CLOSURES: For official map and official Forest closure information around the Blue Fire, please visit https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/klamath/alerts/blue-fire-closure-order.
field_title_and_unit: CAKNF Blue Fire Klamath National Forest

title: Crown Creek Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Crown Creek Fire began on August 29, 2025, following lightning strikes in Stevens County, northeastern Washington. Burning through a mix of grass, brush, and timber in rugged terrain, the fire grew quickly, forcing multiple evacuation levels for nearby communities. By early September, the fire had expanded to several thousand acres, threatening homes, powerlines, property, and livestock. State mobilization was authorized on August 31, bringing in additional resources and strike teams to support local districts/agencies actively involved in initial attack suppression efforts.

At its peak, the fire reached over 14,000 acres. Thanks to favorable weather, aggressive firefighting efforts, and coordination with cooperators, containment steadily increased to more than 90 percent by the end of September. While mop-up, hazard tree removal, and suppression repair continue, officials remain alert to interior hotspots and lingering smoke impacts. The Crown Creek Fire has underscored both the challenges of rapid fire growth in mixed fuels and the importance of strong interagency coordination in protecting local communities. Over the duration of the fire, multiple incident management teams worked toward containment of the fire and implement suppression repair.

Evacuations: All evacuations were lifted on Sept 23, 2025. Stevens County Interactive Evacuation Map is available and allows users to enter their address to identify if they may be impacted by an incident. Information may also be provided on the Stevens County Emergency Management Facebook page as needed.

Emergency Notifications: It is recommend that all residents in the area sign up for emergency notifications through Hyper-Reach for when a future incident occurs. Hyper-reach is Stevens County’s emergency alert system. It provides rapid notification of hazardous and urgent situations through the use of phone calls, texting and email messages. TTY/TDD service is also available for the hearing impaired.

title: Wildcat Fire
field_incident_description: Wildfire
field_incident_overview:
The Wildcat Fire was started by lightning in the William O. Douglas Wilderness and was first reported on Monday, August 25, 2025. It grew slowly until Saturday, August 30, when winds caused increased fire activity, with the fire spotting and flanking. Two helicopters and 4 scooper airtanker aircraft dropped water on the fire. Scoopers dipped water out of Bumping Lake. Fire crews scouted for opportunities to go direct on the 28th and 29th. Increased fire activity on Saturday did not allow this effort to continue. 

Firefighters were challenged with hot and dry conditions, which fueled fire growth. Complex Incident Management NW Team 10 assumed command of the fire on September 3, 2025. On September 16, 2025, the fire was returned to a Type 3 IMT team. The SEWAIMT Team 1 took command of the fire at 0600 on Tuesday, Sep 16, 2025.

Due to extreme fire activity and spread, the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest updated its road, trail and area closure (9/2/25). See the complete order and a map under the "Closures" tab on this site.

Yakima County increased the evacuation level for Goose Prairie and Bumping River Road residents to a LEVEL 2 GET SET.

title: Katy Creek
field_incident_overview:
The Katy Creek Fire started on August 30, 2025, following lightning strikes in the Colville National Forest, northwest of Kettle Falls, Washington. Burning in steep, rocky terrain with heavy timber, the fire posed challenges for direct suppression and required extensive use of hand crews and aerial resources. Early growth reached several hundred acres within days, ultimately expanding to nearly 4,700 acres. The fire threatened nearby structures and prompted road closures and area restrictions to protect public safety. Fire behavior ranged from smoldering and creeping to isolated torching and spotting under dry, windy conditions. Containment steadily increased as crews conducted mop-up, firing operations, and hazard tree mitigation, with the fire reported at over 90 percent contained in late September. Managed in coordination with other regional incidents, the Katy Creek Fire highlighted both the difficulty of firefighting in rugged forest terrain and the effectiveness of coordinated interagency response.

Closures: Colville National Forest initially implemented a closure order for the Katy Creek Fire but reduced the size on Sept 23, 2025.  View the entire order and map on their website.

Evacuations: Ferry County Sheriff's Office lifted all evacuations on Sept 26, 2025. You can get futures alerts about emergencies and other important community news by signing up for the Ferry County Alert System. You will receive time-sensitive messages wherever you specify, such as your home, mobile, or business phones, email address, text messages, and more.

title: White Pine
field_incident_overview:
Public and firefighter safety remain the top priority. Please respect area closures and exercise caution when recreating near the fire. Expect heavier road traffic along ID Hwy 6, FS-768, and FS-1423 as crews move to and from the incident. 

NOTE: Giant White Pine Campground and Laird Park Campground are both currently closed to the public due to the close proximity to this fire and the evolving need to accommodate incoming firefighting personnel.

title: Root Fire
field_incident_overview: The Root Fire was discovered September 1, 2025 north of Castle Creek and west of Castella.  Law enforcement officers from the Forest Service have determined that the Root Fire was caused by an escaped campfire. The fire is burning in Timber understory and grass in steep terrain. Firefighters are working to keep the fire north of Forest Road 39N25; South of the Castle Crags Wilderness; East of Whalen Summit and West of the North Fork of Castle Creek. The fire is burning in steep, rugged terrain with seasonally dry and receptive fuel.

title: Rattlesnake
field_incident_overview:
On September 1, 2025, the Rattlesnake Fire was reported on the Colville Reservation near Inchelium, WA. The fire - named Rattlesnake Fire- is burning in steep thick timber ground and grass sage steep within the old fire scar of the 2003 Rattlesnake Fire. 

Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 7 assumed command at 0600 on September 5th, 2025.

Evacuations orders: There are no evacuations. https://inciweb.wildfire.gov/incident-maps-gallery/wacoa-rattlesnake 

For updates regarding the Rattlesnake Fire, you can follow https://www.facebook.com/CCTBroadcasts on social media. Videos are available to those without Facebook accounts using that link.

Smoke Outlook: Air quality can change quickly. Know your risk to wildfire smoke and plan to reduce exposure. For current smoke reports visit https://fire.airnow.gov

title: Ulm Creek Fire
field_incident_overview: The Ulm Creek Fire, located approximately 6 miles north of Little Guard Peak and approximately 5 miles east of Spion Kop on the ID/MT border. The fire is visible from Heron, Montana. It started on 8/30/2025 from abundant lightning that came through the region. It is burning in the Ulm Peak Fire scar from 2006. Initial attack efforts included district firefighters and engines, a Hotshot crew, and aviation support. Due to unseasonably warm and dry weather, the fire has exceeded initial attack efforts with the largest growth to date occurring between 9/2/2025 and 9/3/2025.

title: Tacoma Creek Fire
field_incident_overview: Tacoma Creek Fire has been returned to the local district for management activities.  This page will no longer be updated.  For current information, please contact NEWICC at 509-685-6900.

title: Green Mtn Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Green Mtn. Fire is located approximately eight miles west of Clark Fork, Idaho and three miles east of Kilroy Bay. The fire was discovered 8/29/2025 at 6:27pm. The fire is located just below Green Monarch Mountain on the upper 1/3 of the slope in difficult terrain overlooking Lake Pend Oreille. Aviation resources were assigned to the fire beginning on 8/30/2025.

Management of the Green Rattle Complex transitioned to the local Blue Team on September 19, 2025 at 6:00 a.m., led by Mitchell Prophet with Ryan Wagner serving as a trainee. Outgoing Northern Rockies Team 9 sincerely thanks the local community for their support and hospitality. The Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) over the complex has been lifted. The Green Rattle Complex is comprised of two fires which began on the Idaho Panhandle National Forests (IPNF) (Green Mtn. and Rattle Mountain) and two fires on the Kootenai National Forest (Spruce and Spruce Ridge).  

Dense, drift smoke from numerous fires in the Pacific Northwest, northern Rocky Mountains, and Canada has the potential to influence weather, as well as cause health hazards for the public. Check on https://www.airnow.gov/ to find out more about smoke and air quality advisories in your area.

title: Log Fire - Klamath National Forest
field_incident_overview:
The Log Fire started in the end of August after several days of thunderstorms passed over the Klamath National Forest. It is burning in a steep and remote area of the Marble Wilderness, about two miles northwest of English Peak. The difficult terrain and competition with other incidents for resources have hampered suppression efforts.

An emergency area closure is in place for the Log Fire, available here: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/klamath/alerts/log-fire-closure-order
field_title_and_unit: CAKNF Log Fire Klamath National Forest

title: Rattle Mountain Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Rattle Mountain Fire was first detected on Tuesday, September 2, 2025, burning adjacent to Rattle Mountain, north of FSR473. The Rattle Mountain Fire is located approximately thirteen miles north/northeast of Clark Fork, Idaho but is also visible from Troy, Montana. 

Management of the Green Rattle Complex transitioned to the local Blue Team on September 19, 2025 at 6:00 a.m., led by Mitchell Prophet with Ryan Wagner serving as a trainee. Outgoing Northern Rockies Team 9 sincerely thanks the local community for their support and hospitality. The Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) over the complex has been lifted.  The Green Rattle Complex is comprised of two fires which began on the Idaho Panhandle National Forests (IPNF) (Green Mtn. and Rattle Mountain) and two fires on the Kootenai National Forest (Spruce and Spruce Ridge).

title: Lower Sugarloaf Fire
field_incident_overview:
Lower Sugarloaf Fire is a lightning-caused fire located near Sugarloaf Lookout. The fire is burning partially in the footprint of the 1994 Tyee Fire and the 2018 Cougar Creek Fire, as well as thick timber and brush that has nor seen fire within record.  

Smoke is very visible to the communities of Plain, Leavenworth, Wenatchee, and Entiat.

Chelan County Sheriff’s Office has issued a Level 1 Evacuation Advisory (Stay Alert), Level 2 Evacuation Notice (Be Ready) and Level 3 Evacuation Alert (Go Now!)  for parts of the fire area, please visit http://bit.ly/4n63ZZF or https://www.co.chelan.wa.us/emer.../pages/active-emergencies for the latest evacuation information.

A Forest Service closure is also in effect around the fire area.  https://inciweb.wildfire.gov/incident-publication/waowf-lower-sugarloaf-fire/lower-sugarloaf-fire-area-forest-closure09-07-2025

title: Labor Mountain Fire
field_incident_overview: The Labor Mountain Fire started on Monday, September 1st. It is burning between Standup and Stafford Creek drainages about 10 miles northeast of Cle Elum, WA. It is actively burning in very steep terrain in one of the drier areas on the Cle Elum Ranger District. The fire is burning in a popular recreation area, with many resources that are at risk, including 12 trailheads, recreation residences, Camp Wahoo and the Teanaway Community Forest and historic guard station. Public and fire fighter safety is the top priority.

title: Cedar Fire
field_incident_overview: The Cedar Fire is being managed by California Interagency Incident Management Team 2 until Tuesday, September 9 at 0700.

title: Snow Peak
field_incident_overview: On September 1, 2025, Snow Peak fire was reported in Ferry County, 19 miles west of Kettle Falls, WA. The fire is located in a remote area approximately 19 miles west of Kettle Falls, WA. The fire is burning in an inventoried roadless area with very difficult access by foot. Resources responding include crews, air attack, and helicopters. The Snow Peak cabin, a valuable recreation site in the alpine area NW of the fire, has been prepped with structure wrap and there have been past fuel treatments in the immediate vicinity of the cabin which significantly lowers the risk of impact.

title: Timber Butte
field_incident_overview:
The Timber Butte fire was reported on the afternoon of September 3rd at approximately 3:00 p.m. Burning in a remote area within the Hidden Pasture Creek Wilderness Area west of Dell, the fire was first reported as visible smoke near Little Water Canyon. Initial attack resources responded, and additional resources were ordered. The fire quickly grew, given the windy conditions associated with the passage of a dry cold front through the area. The fire was estimated at 1,062 acres by the evening hours and 2,245 acres by noon the next day. Given minimal fire behavior, the fire showed no measurable growth over subsequent days.

The fire is burning in steep, rocky terrain in a remote area; these conditions pose challenges to safe access, firefighting operations, and timely medical response if needed.

The fire is burning on lands managed by the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management. 

The cause of the fire is undetermined and is under investigation.

title: Green Rattle Complex
field_incident_overview:
Management of the Green Rattle Complex transitioned to the local Blue Team on September 19, 2025 at 6:00 a.m., led by Mitchell Prophet with Ryan Wagner serving as a trainee. Outgoing Northern Rockies Team 9 sincerely thanks the local community for their support and hospitality. The Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) over the complex has been lifted. The Green Rattle Complex is comprised of the Green Mtn. and Rattle Mountain on the Idaho Panhandle National Forests (IPNF), and a fire on the Kootenai National Forest (Spruce). The Spruce and Spruce Ridge Fires merged on September 13 and is now called the Spruce Fire.

All of the fires are lightning-caused fires which began as the result of storms between Friday, August 29 and Monday, September 2.

The Green Mtn. Fire is located approximately eight miles west of Clark Fork, Idaho. The Rattle Mountain Fire is located approximately thirteen miles north/northeast of Clark Fork, Idaho but is also visible from Troy, Montana. The Spruce Fire is located approximately twelve miles southwest of Troy, Montana.

Green Mtn. Fire:  83 acres; 8% containment

Rattle Mountain Fire:  122 acres; 8% containment

Spruce Fire:  366 acres; 12% containment

TOTAL OVERALL CONTAINMENT: 10%

See the full road and trail closure descriptions on InciWeb, as well as the Idaho Panhandle National Forests and Kootenai National Forest websites: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r01/idahopanhandle/alerts, https://www.fs.usda.gov/r01/kootenai/alerts. A portion of the Green Mtn. Fire area is closed between Johnson Saddle and the FSR2706 intersection, including all roads and trails initiating/bisecting that area (FSR1063, as well as trails 68, 69, and 105). As long as fire activity allows, the Forest will keep FSR2706 open as an alternate route for FSR278; however, forest users are advised that FSR2706 is generally a narrower route, and high-clearance vehicles are advised. There is a separate road closure at FSR332 (Bunco Road), FSR258, FSR534, and FSR911 for timber activities and is unrelated to fire operations. A road closure on a portion of the FSR473 and FSR603 is in place in vicinity of the Spruce and Rattle Mountain fires. Please avoid the general area to allow access for firefighters and equipment.

Dense drift smoke from numerous fires in the Pacific Northwest and northern Rocky Mountains has the potential to influence weather, as well as cause health hazards for the public. Check on https://www.airnow.gov/ to find out more about smoke and air quality advisories in your area.

title: Lynx Mountain
field_incident_overview: The Lynx Mountain Fire is burning 7 miles northwest of Inchelium and northeast of Twin Lakes.  Discovered on Sept. 2, hot, dry days contributed to significant initial fire growth.

title: Perry Fire
field_incident_description: Lightning-caused wildfire north of the Little Beaver drainage west of Ross Lake in North Cascades National Park Service Complex.
field_incident_overview:
On August 27, following storms across the area, a lightning-caused fire was reported north of the Little Beaver drainage west of Ross Lake in North Cascades National Park Service Complex. 

Area, trail, and camp closures: Visitors should check the park Fire Closures page prior to a visit for up-to-date trail and camp closure information. Closures are in place to protect the public.

Fire restrictions: Fire restrictions remain in effect in all areas of the park complex. Campfires are banned in all portions of North Cascades National Park Service Complex – North Cascades National Park, Ross Lake National Recreation Area, and Lake Chelan National Recreation Area. This includes all National Park Service lands and campgrounds along State Route 20 as well as Hozomeen and the entire Stehekin Valley.

title: Marks Creek
field_incident_overview:
The Marks Creek Fire was reported just after noon on September 2nd, burning in timber and brush approximately 18 miles east of Prineville, Oregon on Ochoco National Forest lands. Aggressive initial attack included engines, dozers, single engine super scoopers, helicopters, large air tankers, and other air and ground resources.

The Central Oregon Fire Management Service (COFMS) Type 3 Incident Management Team, Incident Commander Fore, assumed command of the fire the morning of September 3rd.  Operations focused on establishing and strengthening control lines. 

COFMS Type 3 Team transitioned command of the Marks Creek Fire to Oregon Department of Forestry's Complex Incident Management Team 2, Incident Commander Matt Howard at 6:00 p.m. on September 4th. Crews continue to focus operations on reinforcing containment lines, patrolling the perimeter for spot fires and slop overs, and working to construct fireline to limit fire growth.

ODF CIMT 2 transitioned command of the fire to the Prairie Division Type 4 organization from the Ochoco National Forest at 7:00 a.m. on September 12th. Crews will continue to work on suppression repair around the perimeter of the fire.

title: Bridge Fire - OR
field_incident_overview:
The Bridge Fire was reported on 9/3/2025 at 10:29 pm on the Malheur National Forest, within the Blue Mountain Ranger District. The fire is located approximately 9.9 miles northeast of Prairie City, near Dixie Lookout.

Fire crews are actively engaged in suppression efforts, with additional resources enroute to assist. The fire is burning in timber and brush within a steep, and roadless area. The cause of the fire is undetermined at this time. Due to the steep, rugged terrain in which the fire is located and the large amount of heavy, down and dead fuels present, the fire will remain on the landscape until a season ending event such as heavy rain or snow. Firefighters will work to limit the spread of the fire and protect values at risk while accounting for public and firefighter safety.

Motorists traveling along Highway 26 could see increased traffic and visible smoke, as firefighting operations continue.

For all evacuation information please go to:
Genasys Evacuation Map - https://protect.genasys.com/hazards/2001c3ee-af7d-4aa9-827a-232b150669fd?z=10.000105433629999&latlon=44.62346226723207%2C-118.62319026453702

For Closure information please go to:
Malheur National Forest | Bridge Fire Area Closure | Forest Service - https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/malheur/newsroom/releases/bridge-fire-area-closure-updated

title: Moon Complex
field_incident_description: Wildland Fire
field_incident_overview:
Evacuations: On September 26, the Moon Complex experienced rapid fire growth, with long range spot fires and very active fire behavior. New evacuation orders were issued for areas downriver/southwest of the Moon Complex.

Level 3 (GO NOW!) evacuations are in place from Tacoma Rapids / River Mile 29 to Two Mile Creek and Level 2 (SET) evacuations are in place from Two Mile Creek south and east to Oak Flat area. This includes the Agness area.

Bear Camp Road/Forest Service Road 23 has been closed from Galice to Agness. 

The Rogue River has been closed from Grave Creek to Foster Bar. 

On September 3, a lightning event on the Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest caused a number of fires in the vicinity of the Rogue River about 10 miles northeast of Agness, Oregon. Six of these made up the initial Moon Complex: the Backbone, Brushy, Pinnacle, Tate, Paradise, and Stair fires. As of September 8, Paradise, Stair, and Brushy fires burned into the perimeters of other fires. Tate Fire is fully contained at 26 acres. Suppression work continued on the Backbone and Pinnacle fires. 

On September 26, the Backbone and Pinnacle fires merged, and will now be referred to as the Pinnacle Fire.

Fire Restrictions are in effect: Stage III fire restrictions went into effect on the Wild and Scenic Lower Rogue River on Friday, August 15, 2025. Building, maintaining, attending, or use of a fire is not permitted. To learn more, visit: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/rogue-siskiyou/alerts/stage-3-public-use-restrictions-wild-and-scenic-lower-rogue-river

title: Kelsey Peak Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Kelsey Peak Fire is located 15 miles west of Glendale in the Lower Rogue River Corridor on Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Medford District administered lands. The Kelsey Peak Fire, along with numerous other fires, was sparked by passing thunderstorms on September 3, 2025. Initial attack by Oregon Department of Forestry’s (ODF) Southwest Oregon District was immediate. Despite aggressive firefighting tactics by local agencies over the next several days, the fire continued to grow.

Extended attack on the fire continued to challenge firefighters in steep, rugged terrain with persistent smoke halting air operations. ODF Complex Incident Management Team 1, Incident Commander Dan Quinones, was ordered on September 6 to manage suppression efforts on the Kelsey Peak Fire. Team 1 was in-briefed by ODF and BLM on Sunday, September 7, with transfer of command at 6:00 a.m. Monday, September 8.

title: Black Rock Fire
field_incident_description: Black Rock Fire was reported on September 4, 2025 at 6:29pm.  The location was five miles north of Clarno, OR on the west side of the John Day River.
field_incident_overview: Black Rock Fire was reported on September 4, 2025 at 6:29pm.  The location was five miles north of Clarno, OR on the west side of the John Day River.

title: Isabella and Lost Girl Fires
field_incident_description:
The fires occurred in steep terrain with heavy fuel loading with little to no road access. Suppression tactics were based on several safety concerns, including a lack of ingress and egress options that would result in unacceptable medevac times. Decisions are heavily based on firefighter safety and resources at risk. Resources continue to assess for opportunities for direct and indirect options.
A Type 3 Incident Commander has taken command of the fires. Crews and heavy equipment continue to prepare roads and trails to utilize as containment points if the fires continue to grow. There are currently no immediate concerns to private infrastructure. Smoke from the fires are visible along the Hwy 56 corridor.

A closure order is pending for roads and trails in the vicinity of the fires.
field_incident_overview:
On August 31st, a lightning storm ignited 31 fires across the Kootenai National Forest.  Firefighting resources, (engines and hand crew modules) responded to these fires throughout the evening of Aug 31st and in the morning on September 1st. 10 lightning fires were ignited on the Cabinet Ranger District including the Isabella, Moran, and Lost Girl Fires which started in the Cabinet Mountain Wilderness.  Kootenai Rappelers were inserted into the Lost Girl fire on the evening of the August 31st.  Active fire behavior combined with difficult access and extremely steep and cliffy terrain compromised the safety of firefighters during this initial suppression efforts and firefighters disengaged ground operation.  A Type 3 Incident Commander has taken command of the fires. Crews and heavy equipment continue to prepare roads and trails to utilize as containment points if the fires continue to grow. There are currently no immediate concerns to private infrastructure. 

Isabella: Start Date: 09/01/2025; Size: 1,095 acres as of September 22, 2025

Lost Girl: Start Date: 08/31/2025; Size: 280 acres as of September 22, 2025

Moran Fire: Start Date: 08/31/2025; Size: .2 acres as of September 6, 2025 -The fire has not shown any smoke or heat for several days

*Updates will be made with any significant changes in fire behavior or growth. Updates may not occur daily.
field_title_and_unit: MTKNF Isabella and Lost Girl Fires

title: Foley Ridge Fire
field_incident_description: The lightning-caused Foley Ridge Fire was reported on September 6 and is located on a cliff visible from Oregon Highway 242 (McKenzie Highway) approximately seven miles east of McKenzie Bridge
field_incident_overview:
The lightning-caused Foley Ridge Fire was reported on September 6 and is located on a cliff visible from Oregon Highway 242 (McKenzie Highway) approximately seven miles east of McKenzie Bridge. 

Crews, dozers, engines, and helicopters are aggressively engaging to fully suppress the fire.

title: Transfer Road Prescribed Burn
field_incident_description:
Objectives:

Reduce hazardous fuels to mitigate risk of extreme wildfire behavior

Improve habitat for elk and deer

Operational Details:

The overall prescribed burn project area contains multiple units to be burned given the proper environmental conditions

Burn will be conducted on BLM-managed lands

Fire crews will be on site during ignition and for several days post-burn

Smoke will be visible during the day and may settle in low-lying areas overnight
field_incident_overview:
🔥 Prescribed Burn Planned Near Transfer Road – Fall 2025 🔥

The Bureau of Land Management’s Uncompahgre Field Office will conduct a broadcast prescribed burn southwest of Olathe this fall (September–October), along the BLM/Forest Service boundary near Transfer Road. 

This burn is part of a proactive strategy to reduce hazardous fuels and lower the risk of extreme wildfire behavior, as seen in recent local fires (South Rim, Turner Gulch, Sowbelly). It also aims to improve habitat for elk and deer while helping protect nearby private property and critical infrastructure from future wildfire threats.

📅 Timing: Dependent on favorable weather and fire conditions 

👨‍🚒 On-Site Crews: Firefighters will be present during ignition and will monitor the area for several days post-burn

 🌫️ Smoke Notice: Expect visible smoke during the day, especially in warmer hours. Evening smoke may settle in low-lying areas 

🏠 Community Safety: Crews will take precautions to safeguard adjacent private lands, homes, and infrastructure throughout the operation

 

Please check back for future dates and burn announcements.

title: Superior National Forest Planned Prescribed Fires-Fall 2025
field_incident_description: These prescribed fires reduce risk to the public by removing hazardous vegetation to mitigate wildfires and prevent loss of property. They also help to reestablish fire’s positive role in local ecosystems, increase native plant regeneration, and improve wildlife habitat and forest health.
field_incident_overview:
Superior National Forest has started fall prescribed fire operations with pile burning. We estimate this work to continue through December as weather conditions allow. We use prescribed fires to help reduce overgrown vegetation to help protect local communities, infrastructure and natural resources from wildfires. 

Several factors including fuel moisture, relative humidity, temperature, and wind will be used to determine the actual date of ignition. We will evaluate weather conditions in the hours before a burn begins. If conditions are not conducive for objectives, scheduled prescribed fire activities may be canceled.

Pile burn locations are located on the maps tab of this page. 

If prescribed fires are close to the roads, signs will be posted for awareness. When driving, slow down and turn on your headlights when you encounter smoke on the road and watch for firefighters. Residents may experience smoke during the prescribed burns. Go to https://fire.airnow.gov/ for detailed information about air quality. 

Stay informed about the scheduled prescribed fires through the forest website, social media channels, and InciWeb, the interagency incident information system. We will notify county emergency management officials when prescribed fire begins.  

Gunflint-Prescribed pile burning will begin September-December 2025 for a total of 1,547 acres

  • Hound 3–T61N, R1W, Sec10 (54 acres)-Completed
  • Nova 4–T60N, R2E, Sec7 (39 acres)-Completed
  • Atlas–T63N, R1E, Sec15 (6 acres)
  • Rescue 7, 8, 10 & 11–T64N, R1E, Sec20,21, & 27 (193 acres)-Completed
  • East Bearskin 1 & 2–T64N, R1W, Sec12 (130 acres)
  • Squint–T64N, R1W, Sec9 (118 acres)
  • Hungry Jack–T65N, R1W, Sec34 (152 acres)
  • Flour–T64N, R1W, Sec 1,2, & 11 (138 acres)
  • Caribou–T65N, R1W, Sec33 (68 acres)
  • Seagull Guard Station–T65N, R4W, Sec9 (10 acres)
  • Airport–T62N, R1W, Sec23 (40 acres)
  • Menogyn–T65N, R1W, Sec34 (12 acres)
  • Cross River–T65N, R4W, Sec26 (40 acres)
  • Greenwood–T61N, R2W, Sec14 (40 acres)
  • East Bearskin–T64N, R1W, Sec 11 (40 acres)
  • Pike Lake–T61N, R2W, Sec14 (40 acres)

Tofte-Prescribed pile burning will begin September-December 2025 for a total of 1,635 acres 

  • Eddy 1, 2, 7, 10, 11, 14 & 17–T61N, R9W, Sec 15, 16, 21 & 22 (171 acres)
  • Fry 4 & 5–T60N, R4W, Sec8, 9, 15 & 15 (28 acres)
  • Little Isabella Campground–T60N, R9W, Sec25 (14 acres)

field_title_and_unit: MNSUF Superior National Forest Planned Prescribed FiresFall 2025

title: Tunnel Creek Fire
field_incident_overview:
On September 6, 2025, USFS fire managers were able to assess a new fire start caused by lightning, named the Tunnel Creek Fire, located in a remote area of the Buckhorn Wilderness in Olympic National Forest.

The fire is roughly 10 miles west of Quilcene, Washington and 1.5 miles west of the Tunnel Creek Trailhead accessed from FS Road 2740.

title: Heat Wave Fire
field_incident_description: Wildfire burning east of Baird, Texas.
field_incident_overview: The Heat Wave Fire started on September 22, 2025 in Callahan County, approximately 4 miles east of Baird, Texas. It was initially responded to by local fire departments. Texas A&M Forest Service was requested to provide assistance in the form of additional firefighters and heavy equipment at 1:30 pm and quickly responded. Texas A&M Forest Service is currently in unified command with local fire departments. Aviation resources have been assigned to this fire. Crews on the ground are working to construct containment lines around the outside of the fire with bulldozers.

title: Helena-Lewis and Clark NF Rx Fires
field_incident_description: On Wednesday, Sept. 24 we will be burning 187 acres in the School House units located in Travis Creek in Jefferson County. Smoke may be visible from the Helena Valley and the I-15 corridor. On Sunday, Sept. 28, fire personnel plan to burn 300 acres in the Wakina Sky area of Helena's South Hills. Smoke may be visible from downtown Helena. Although debris burning is closed in both Lewis and Clark County and Jefferson County, the Helena Ranger District has been coordinating with both counties closely and has received support for prescribed burning. Qualified burn bosses along with 6 or more Type 6 engines, 1 20 person Type 2 IA crew and multiple local resources will be on scene of the units. The US Forest Service, Montana DNRC, and local Volunteer Fire Departments will be providing resources to successfully implement the burn and gain experience across jurisdictions with prescribed burning.
field_incident_overview:
The Helena-Lewis and Clark National Forest is planning prescribed fire operations beginning this week, pending all required approvals. We estimate this work to continue through mid-October as weather conditions allow. We use prescribed fires to help reduce overgrown vegetation to help protect local communities, infrastructure and natural resources from wildfires.

Prescribed fires planned for early fall include:

  • Rocky Mountain Ranger District – 150 acres in Benchmark corridor, west of Augusta (combo of broadcast & piles) in early October.
  • Belt Creek-White Sulphur Springs Ranger District – 260 acres 15 miles northeast of White Sulphur Springs, anticipated near the end of September/early October.
  • Townsend Ranger District – 71 acres in Cabin Gulch, east of Townsend, likely near end of September/ early October.
  • Helena Ranger District – 3,500 acres across multiple project areas (i.e., Tenmile-South Helena, Telegraph, and Middleman). This work will begin in the Travis Creek area (Wednesday) and Wakina Sky area in Helena’s South Hills (Sunday).

Watch for warning signs along roads near all prescribed fire areas before and during burns. 

Residents may experience smoke during the prescribed burns. Go to https://fire.airnow.gov/ to find more detailed information about air quality. When driving, slow down and turn on your headlights when you encounter smoke on the road.

We will evaluate weather conditions in the hours before a burn begins. If conditions warrant, scheduled prescribed fire activities may be canceled.
field_title_and_unit: MTHLF HelenaLewis and Clark NF Rx Fires

title: Burned Area Emergency Response, Garnet Fire, USFS
field_incident_description: Evaluating Burned Area Emergency Response on 59,844 acres on the Sierra National Forest.
field_incident_overview: A U S Forest Service Burned Area Emergency Response (BAER) team, led by Marcos Rios, started burn area surveys on September 17 on the Sierra National Forest. The Garnet fire burned approximately 59,844 acres. BAER team assessments are rapid evaluations of post-fire conditions of the burned landscape to determine the level of risk from potential flooding and debris flow to values on National Forest System lands. If unacceptable risks are found the team recommends appropriate and effective emergency stabilization measures to reduce the risks to national forest lands and values. BAER emergency stabilization efforts are focused on the protection of human life and safety, property, and critical cultural and natural resources.
field_title_and_unit: CASNF Burned Area Emergency Response Garnet Fire USFS

title: Upper River Prescribed Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Coeur d’Alene River Ranger District of the Idaho Panhandle National Forests plans to burn up to 2,350 acres across portions of 11 units within the Upper Coeur d’Alene River drainage and its tributaries during Fall 2025 (September-October) if the desired weather, soil moisture, and smoke dispersal conditions occur. Ignitions will cease if there is a change in burning conditions or management objectives are not being met. Smoke may be visible in the area for several days after the ignitions phase of the prescribed fire is complete. The Forest Service will monitor the prescribed fires until they are completely out.

The project location is within the Upper North Fork Coeur d’Alene River Basin and its tributaries including Buckskin, Cinnamon, Forks, Marten, Spion Kop, Stony, Swift, Taft, and Tepee Creeks. Potentially impacted National Forest Systems Trails include 20, 81, 244, and 309. Potentially impacted National Forest System Roads include 208 (Coeur d’Alene River Road), 306, 600, 1533, 2360A, 3099, and 6310 (Tepee Creek Road).

title: Sheep Drive
field_incident_overview: Sheep Drive is a lightning-caused wildfire that was detected after a recent thunderstorm. This fire is in extremely steep, rugged, terrain making access difficult. There are no closures currently associated with this fire but the potential to impact FS Trail #505 is high.
